Apple___Apple_scab.description: Apple scab is a common fungal disease of apple and crabapple trees. It causes olive-green to brown spots on leaves, fruit, and twigs. Severe infections can lead to defoliation and reduced fruit quality.
Apple___Apple_scab.symptoms: Olive-green to brown spots on leaves, often with a velvety texture. Spots on fruit are dark, circular, and may become corky. Leaves may yellow and drop prematurely.

Apple___Black_rot.description: Black rot is a fungal disease affecting apples, causing dark, sunken lesions on fruit, leaf spots, and cankers on branches. It can lead to significant fruit loss.
Apple___Black_rot.symptoms: Dark, circular, sunken lesions on fruit, often with concentric rings. Purple-bordered brown spots on leaves ('frogeye leaf spot'). Cankers on branches.

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.description: Cedar apple rust is a fungal disease that requires both apple/crabapple and cedar/juniper trees to complete its life cycle. It causes bright orange spots on apple leaves.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.symptoms: Bright orange-yellow spots on apple leaves, often with small black dots (pycnia) in the center. Lesions may also appear on fruit.

Apple___healthy.description: The apple plant shows no signs of disease and appears to be in good health.
Apple___healthy.symptoms: Vibrant green leaves, strong branches, and healthy fruit development. No discoloration, spots, or wilting observed.

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.disease: Cercospora Leaf Spot / Gray Leaf Spot
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.description: Gray leaf spot is a fungal disease of corn caused by Cercospora zeae-maydis. It produces rectangular, gray-brown lesions on leaves, reducing photosynthetic area and yield.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.symptoms: Long, narrow, rectangular lesions (gray-brown) on leaves, typically parallel to the leaf veins. Lesions may coalesce, causing blighting of leaves.

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.description: Common rust is a fungal disease of corn caused by Puccinia sorghi. It appears as small, cinnamon-brown pustules on both sides of leaves, which release spores.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.symptoms: Small, circular to oval, cinnamon-brown pustules on both upper and lower leaf surfaces. Pustules may rupture, releasing powdery rust spores.

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.description: Northern leaf blight is a fungal disease caused by Exserohilum turcicum. It creates long, elliptical, gray-green lesions on corn leaves, leading to significant yield loss in severe cases.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.symptoms: Long, elliptical, cigar-shaped lesions (gray-green to tan) on leaves, often starting on lower leaves and progressing upwards. Lesions may coalesce.

Corn_(maize)___healthy.description: The corn plant shows no signs of disease and appears to be in good health.
Corn_(maize)___healthy.symptoms: Vibrant green leaves, strong stalks, and healthy ear development. No discoloration, spots, or wilting observed.

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot is a common and destructive disease of peppers and tomatoes caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria. It causes dark, water-soaked spots on leaves and fruit.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Small, dark, water-soaked spots on leaves that become angular and necrotic with yellow halos. Raised, scab-like lesions on fruit.

Pepper,_bell___healthy.description: The bell pepper plant shows no signs of disease and appears to be in good health.
Pepper,_bell___healthy.symptoms: Vibrant green leaves, strong stems, and healthy fruit development. No discoloration, spots, or wilting observed.

Potato___Early_blight.description: Early blight is a common fungal disease of potatoes caused by Alternaria solani. It causes characteristic target-like spots on leaves, leading to premature defoliation.
Potato___Early_blight.symptoms: Dark brown to black spots on older leaves, often with concentric rings (target-like appearance). Yellowing of tissue around spots. Lesions on stems and tubers.

Potato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is a highly destructive disease of potatoes caused by Phytophthora infestans. It can rapidly destroy foliage and tubers, especially in cool, wet conditions.
Potato___Late_blight.symptoms: Large, irregular, water-soaked lesions on leaves that turn brown/black. A fuzzy white mold may be visible on the underside of leaves. Brown, firm rot on tubers.

Potato___healthy.description: The potato plant shows no signs of disease and appears to be in good health.
Potato___healthy.symptoms: Vibrant green leaves, strong stems, and healthy tuber development. No discoloration, spots, or wilting observed.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot is a common and destructive disease of tomatoes and peppers caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria. It causes dark, water-soaked spots on leaves and fruit.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Small, dark, water-soaked spots on leaves that become angular and necrotic with yellow halos. Raised, scab-like lesions on fruit.

Tomato___Early_blight.description: Early blight is a common fungal disease of tomatoes caused by Alternaria solani. It causes characteristic target-like spots on leaves, leading to premature defoliation.
Tomato___Early_blight.symptoms: Dark brown to black spots on older leaves, often with concentric rings (target-like appearance). Yellowing of tissue around spots. Lesions on stems and fruit.

Tomato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is a devastating disease of tomato and potato caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans. It thrives in cool, wet conditions and can rapidly destroy entire crops.
Tomato___Late_blight.symptoms: Large, irregular, water-soaked spots on leaves that quickly turn brown or black. A fuzzy white mold may be visible on the underside of leaves in humid conditions. Brown, firm spots on fruit.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold is a fungal disease of tomatoes caused by Passalora fulva. It thrives in high humidity and causes velvety, olive-green to brown patches on the undersides of leaves.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.symptoms: Yellowish spots on the upper leaf surface, corresponding to olive-green to brown, velvety fungal growth on the underside. Leaves may curl and drop.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria leaf spot is a common fungal disease of tomatoes caused by Septoria lycopersici. It causes numerous small, circular spots with dark borders and tiny black dots in the center.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.symptoms: Numerous small, circular spots (1/16 to 1/4 inch) on lower leaves, with dark brown borders and tan to gray centers. Tiny black dots (pycnidia) are visible in the center of spots.

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.description: Two-spotted spider mites are tiny arachnids that feed on plant sap, causing stippling, yellowing, and bronzing of leaves. Severe infestations can lead to defoliation and reduced yield.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.symptoms: Tiny yellow or white stippling on leaves. Fine webbing on the undersides of leaves or between leaves and stems. Leaves may turn yellow, bronze, or brown and drop prematurely.

Tomato___Target_Spot.description: Target spot is a fungal disease of tomatoes caused by Corynespora cassiicola. It produces distinctive circular lesions with concentric rings, resembling a target.
Tomato___Target_Spot.symptoms: Small, dark, circular spots on older leaves that enlarge and develop concentric rings (target-like appearance). Spots may also appear on stems and fruit.

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV) is a devastating viral disease transmitted by whiteflies. It causes severe stunting, yellowing, and upward curling of leaves, leading to significant yield loss.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.symptoms: Severe stunting of plants. Upward curling and yellowing of leaf margins. Reduced leaf size. Flowers may drop, and fruit set is poor or absent.

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV) is a highly contagious viral disease that causes mosaic patterns on leaves, stunting, and malformed fruit. It is easily spread by contact.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.symptoms: Light and dark green mosaic or mottling patterns on leaves. Leaves may be distorted, puckered, or fern-like. Stunting of plants. Fruit may be malformed or have uneven ripening.

Tomato___healthy.description: The tomato plant shows no signs of disease and appears to be in good health.
Tomato___healthy.symptoms: Vibrant green leaves, strong stems, and healthy fruit development. No discoloration, spots, or wilting observed.
